No more I carol amatory strains,</br>To friendship's eye submit the artless lay;</br>Pourtray the scenes where sylvan beauty reigns,</br>Or in light measure sing mellifluous May.
No more I tread the rill-dissected mead,</br>The thymy bank, and beach-surrounded field,</br>Where bleating ewes and sportive lambkins feed,</br>No more the groves their wonted transports yield.
Yet not to ease and indolence a prey,</br>To pleasure's syren call a willing slave,</br>My unbefriended Muse shall pensive stray</br>To lone retreats that Medway's currents lave.
Where peaceful virtues in sequestered train</br>The circling moor with splendid crescent thrones,</br>Silvers the Gothic pile and sacred fane,</br>The mould'ring turret and the moss-clad stones.
There, where the cypress and the mournful pine</br>Join in the breezy dirges of the night,</br>An altar rais'd, and Melancholy mine,</br>I'll taste her ever pensive, sad delight.
My theme the herald of no war's alarms,</br>Of grandeur, power, of honour, or of fame;</br>Of structures lost to all their former charms,</br>Mingled in dust, and found but by a name.
More arduous far the Muse's task's assign'd;</br>Thy aid, Melpomene, her efforts crave,</br>Whilst she reviews the ruins of the mind,</br>Poor Reason, buried in the body's grave.
O Reason, lamp that lights the busy soul,</br>To govern human passion kindly giv'n;</br>Our faith, our joys, and sorrows, to controul;</br>Thou brightest mirror of reflected Heav'n:
Blest taper, lighting to Religion's throne,</br>Ah!  what were man without thy genial sway!</br>His hopes how frail!  how little had he known,</br>Without thy strong and unerroneous ray!
Poor insects had we been in nature's scale,</br>Consign'd to dullness, levell'd with the brute;</br>The wanton sport of Folly's vicious gale;</br>Of Wisdom's tree precluded from the fruit.
Reason depos'd, how art thou sunk, O Man?</br>Hoodwink'd thy mind, ah!  where is then thy boast?</br>Confus'dly restless, and without a plan,</br>Immers'd in doubt, and to reflection lost.
So yon fair seat of elegance and taste,</br>Which spread its charms to admiration's eye,</br>Destroy'd, behold a desolated waste,</br>And low in dust its splendid honours lie.
—Worst Pandemonium of the human mind,</br>Tremendous Madness — who's exempt from thee?</br>The weak, the strong, the brave, thy shackles bind,</br>And victims fall to thy severe decree.
How vast thy havoc o'er the human form,</br>O'er beauty, mem'ry, excellence, and sense:</br>Perfection's safe not from thy ruthless storm,</br>And wit or learning but a feeble fence.
How shall the Muse thy varied woes recite,</br>Thy wild ideas, foster'd in the brain,</br>That warm the cheated soul with fond delight,</br>Or form huge phantoms of fictitious pain.
Yet her's the task, she strives the course to steer,</br>With diffidence expands the vent'rous sail,</br>While heterogeneous sounds distract the ear,</br>And urge her passage thro' Misfortune's vale.
Behold that stately figure — Child of Pride!</br>I knew him ere to madness thus a prey,</br>When self-importance urg'd him to deride,</br>And scarcely own a great Creator's sway.
And now in all the mockery of state,</br>Tho' clad in rags, this ostentatious thing</br>Believes around him thousand slaves await,</br>Himself in fancy a despotic King.
Thus human nature, when o'ercast with pride,</br>Insulted Heav'n most severely scans;</br>Of arrogance repels th' impetuous tide,</br>Humbles rank insolence, and man unmans.
All dark within — Olivia, love-lorn maid,</br>In tatter'd garb, and with dishevell'd hair,</br>Avoids the light, of faithless man afraid,</br>Her haggard form the picture of despair.
Ask you the cause why poor Olivia's lost,</br>Her spirits broke, her bosom swoln with woe?</br>By slighted vows and disappointment cross'd,</br>Distraction urg'd her eyes to overflow.
Blushes the hectic on her pallid cheek,</br>Where lively breath'd the sweetly living rose:</br>Of sorrows past now hear her piteous speak;</br>Of sorrows past a Cazonette compose.
She sings; 'tis melody's most plaintive strain,</br>Big with a sigh, and usher'd with a tear;</br>Ever and anon abridg'd by pain,</br>And check'd with sudden starts of grief or fear.
And now in moody silence see she sits,</br>Absorb'd in apathy or mental gloom;</br>Or rous'd — bewails, or laughs, or sings, by fits;</br>Reviles, condemns, or calls she knows not whom.
That piteous object which our ears assails</br>With clam'rous rage and ceaseless discontent,</br>Attacking with his teeth his squalid nails,</br>Desp'rate in thought, on sable mischief bent.
Bright as the sun before th' approaching storm,</br>He shone conspicuous in the rings of taste;</br>But passion reason to deform,</br>Her fruitful soil becomes a dreary waste.
In midnight orgies were his moments past?</br>Was dissipation his without controul?</br>The reckonings came and finish'd the repast,</br>And pale distraction overwhelms his soul.
Who's this all mirth and mummery we see,</br>That laughs at fortune, pomp, and wealth, and pow'r;</br>From pride and malice, and from sorrow free,</br>The very May fly of the frantic hour.
Behold her brisk with freakish step advance,</br>In every gesture, every gambol shown,</br>On toe fantastic round and round she'll dance,</br>And deem the fairy regions all her own.
'Twas her's to flirt, and only seem sincere,</br>The vain coquet, with blandishments her own,</br>To laugh, to sing, to wheedle, and to jeer,</br>'Till Reason lost its unsubstantial throne.
No stings of mem'ry to her vacant mind</br>Reflection's busy images convey;</br>Tho' sad her friends, herself to mirth inclin'd,</br>Is ne'er unhappy, never less than gay.
Charming delusion!  when distraction reigns,</br>And fancied pleasure's false ideas range:</br>But when black choler stagnates in the veins,</br>Behold and mark the melancholy change.
His words how broken!  faul'tring!  and how slow!</br>Sunk into darkness like a fallen star.</br>Melanthus view immers'd in sullen woe,</br>The door of reason does despondence bar.
The poor fanatic, buried in despair,</br>Madly anticipates each future pain;</br>Caught in some bigot's unrelenting snare,</br>Religion stretches out her hand in vain.
Dark as his brow — the chaos of his mind</br>Presents eternal torments to his sight;</br>A Deity no longer good and kind:</br>His apprehensions endless fears excite.
Ill-founded fear!  but who shall comfort bring,</br>When wild Enthusiasm occupies the breast;</br>When horrors hence delusion's visions bring,</br>To rob Devotion of her purest rest.
O Melancholy!  'tis thine, in varied shape,</br>The voice of Peace and Pleasure to suppress,</br>To bind the brows of Reason with thy crape,</br>And o'er the mind thy leaden weights to press.
And Avarice thine!  fell canker of each joy,</br>Fast foe to honour, pure fruition's bane:</br>How much the human mind thy cares annoy,</br>The wretch that's next in view can well explain.
Unsocial mortal, opulently poor,</br>Deaf to Misfortune's penetrating plaint,</br>He spurn'd poor shiv'ring merit from his door,</br>And starv'd midst plenty, making gold his saint.
This Miserfranke, in epitome,</br>Still is himself, altho' in madden'd plight,</br>Collecting bits of rags, or leaves of tea,</br>As hoards, in Fancy's eye, immensely bright.
The Poet's dreams, his frenzy rolling eye,</br>The Muse might paint, but ceases to intrude.</br>Or jealous Rage, or fell Misanthropy,</br>And other various shapes of Reason crude,
Curtails her flight as tender feelings rise,</br>And conscious tears protract the mournful tale,</br>Which speaks my heart in sympathetic sighs,</br>And kindred Nature drops Compassion's veil.</br>
